awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Broadband and All-in-One Optical Workstation for Micro-scale Vibration and Topography Measurement
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the acquisition of an all-in-one optical measurement workstation instrument with micro-scale vibration and topography characterization capabilities. The instrument will enhance research and education capacity in the mountain west and enhance collaborations at regional industries and universities. It will catalyze interdisciplinary and fundamental research involving additive manufacturing, materials science, biomedical engineering, and quantum physics. Integrated into course projects and research lab internships, the instrument will enhance the science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) diversity and retention at Boise State University. The instrument will also be used for outreach activities with K-12 students and educators in the state of Idaho, to enhance STEM recruitment. 

The instrument consists of a laser doppler vibrometer enabling sub-picometer magnitude vibration measurement up to 2.4 GHz and a white light interferometer enabling three-dimensional surface topography down to sub-nanometer resolution. The laser doppler vibrometer can visualize acoustic wave propagation in various materials, including alloys, ceramics, soft tissues, particulate composites, and printed porous films. Transformative research on these materials will potentially lead to advanced ultrasonic sensors for nuclear reactors, innovative bioscaffolds for tissue engineering, efficient embedded neuro stimulators, and novel quantum information delivery methods. The white light interferometer can detect microstructure morphing in real-time. Along with customized electromagnets or heat sources, the instrument will provide unprecedented material properties of smart materials, such as magnetostrictive materials and magnetic shape memory alloys. The fundamental understanding of these multiphysics and multifunctional materials will result in new devices for structural health monitoring or drug delivery.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to acquire a Polytec MSA-600-X/U micro analyzer, an advanced tool capable of measuring high-frequency mechanical vibrations and high-resolution surface topography. This instrument was installed and calibrated on June 21-22, 2023. Polytec technicians provided the initial round of training to two lab managers at Boise State University, one faculty member, six Boise State students, one graduate student from the University of Colorado Boulder, and a research scientist from Idaho National Laboratory. An additional X-Y micro stage was installed on August 16, 2023, and a second round of training, focused on data stitching, was conducted. Boise State University has integrated this new instrument into the iLab system to facilitate scheduling and management. Additionally, our IT team configured the system for Google Drive integration, enabling more convenient data storage and access. This instrument is now readily accessible for use by both internal and external collaborators.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in the expanded knowledge base it enables, with transformative potential in active additive manufacturing and microstructure characterization research. The tool has been instrumental in characterizing the multiphysics properties of printed materials and analyzing acoustic wave propagation in extreme environments. This work contributed to the successful acquisition of a DOE grant (no. DE-NE0009501), which commenced on August 1, 2024. The instrument has also supported research on multifunctional printed sensors designed to monitor human health, aiding a Research Project Lead project under the NIH Convergent Engineering and Biomolecular Science (CEBS) Center of Biomedical Research Excellence (COBRE). Several additional grants, leveraging the instrument's unique capabilities, are pending. By the end of the project, two conference publications were produced under this award, with one paper earning 2nd place in the Best Student Paper competition at the 2024 SPIE Smart Materials + NDE Conference in Los Angeles, California.

The project’s broader impact is evident in community outreach and commercialization activities. The instrument was featured in the Student Innovation & Design Event, a community outreach initiative during the fall 2024 semester, where 20 juniors from Columbia High School in Nampa, ID, toured the facility. Additionally, the instrument has provided critical data for multifunctional sensor research, which has led to a pending patent application and entrepreneur seed grants.

This project has strengthened research capacity in the Mountain West, enhanced collaborations with Idaho National Laboratory, and expanded partnerships with universities in Colorado and Montana.


Last Modified: 11/18/2024
Modified by: Zhangxian Deng
